What is tidy data?

data-cleaning
Author

Robert Muwanga

Published

May 28, 2025

Background

Tidy data is a philosophy often used in the data analysis circles to help structure data before using it for analysis. Although getting it into this form is a lot of hard work, it is akin to sharpening the axe before cutting down a tree - it may be a lot of work to get the tool (data) in the right state but it pays off immensely once the cutting (analysis) starts.

In the R community, putting your data in a tidy state allows one to leverage on the tidyverse packages that are created to operate on data complying with this philosophy. This philosophy, coupled with packages that comply with it, makes analysis such a joy.

This article is focused on helping you understand what it means to have data in a tidy state.

Principles behind tidy data

Data can be represented in several ways. Consider a simple dataset that shows a table of Series with their release date, genre, IMDB rating and director.

Table 1 might looks like the following:

Series_Title Release Genre IMDB_Rating Director
The Shawshank Redemption 1994 Drama 9.3 Frank Darabont
The Godfather 1972 Crime 9.2 Francis Ford Coppola
The Dark Knight 2008 Action 9.0 Christopher Nolan
The Godfather: Part II 1974 Crime 9.0 Francis Ford Coppola
12 Angry Men 1957 Crime 9.0 Sidney Lumet
The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King 2003 Action 8.9 Peter Jackson
Pulp Fiction 1994 Crime 8.9 Quentin Tarantino
Schindler's List 1993 Biography 8.9 Steven Spielberg
Inception 2010 Action 8.8 Christopher Nolan
Fight Club 1999 Drama 8.8 David Fincher

Table 2, containing the same data, might look like this:

Release Genre IMDB_Rating Director Series_Title_Rating
1994 Drama 9.3 Frank Darabont The Shawshank Redemption , 9.3
1972 Crime 9.2 Francis Ford Coppola The Godfather , 9.2
2008 Action 9.0 Christopher Nolan The Dark Knight , 9
1974 Crime 9.0 Francis Ford Coppola The Godfather: Part II , 9
1957 Crime 9.0 Sidney Lumet 12 Angry Men , 9
2003 Action 8.9 Peter Jackson The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King , 8.9
1994 Crime 8.9 Quentin Tarantino Pulp Fiction , 8.9
1993 Biography 8.9 Steven Spielberg Schindler's List , 8.9
2010 Action 8.8 Christopher Nolan Inception , 8.8
1999 Drama 8.8 David Fincher Fight Club , 8.8

Or Table 3 could be structured like this:

Series Details
The Shawshank Redemption Frank Darabont , Drama , 1994 , 9.3
The Godfather Francis Ford Coppola , Crime , 1972 , 9.2
The Dark Knight Christopher Nolan , Action , 2008 , 9
The Godfather: Part II Francis Ford Coppola , Crime , 1974 , 9
12 Angry Men Sidney Lumet , Crime , 1957 , 9
The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King Peter Jackson , Action , 2003 , 8.9
Pulp Fiction Quentin Tarantino , Crime , 1994 , 8.9
Schindler's List Steven Spielberg , Biography , 1993 , 8.9
Inception Christopher Nolan , Action , 2010 , 8.8
Fight Club David Fincher , Drama , 1999 , 8.8

In all these three instances, the data representation is perfectly valid but each one is harder to use in analysis (particularly the third table!)

The first table is the easiest to use as it follows the three tidy principles:

  1. Each column is a variable.
  2. Each row is an observation.
  3. Each cell (intersection between the column and row) is a SINGLE value.

These simple principles allows for data to be stored consistently, and allows for R to leverage on its vectorised approach processing data, i.e., a tidy function can perform the same transformation along a variable consistently if the data within that variable is the same.

For example, converting the IMDB_rating variable in the first table to a percentage would be as simple as multiplying the variable by 10 (existing rating is out of 10):

Series_Title Release Genre IMDB_Rating Director
The Shawshank Redemption 1994 Drama 93 Frank Darabont
The Godfather 1972 Crime 92 Francis Ford Coppola
The Dark Knight 2008 Action 90 Christopher Nolan
The Godfather: Part II 1974 Crime 90 Francis Ford Coppola
12 Angry Men 1957 Crime 90 Sidney Lumet
The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King 2003 Action 89 Peter Jackson
Pulp Fiction 1994 Crime 89 Quentin Tarantino
Schindler's List 1993 Biography 89 Steven Spielberg
Inception 2010 Action 88 Christopher Nolan
Fight Club 1999 Drama 88 David Fincher

A Simple Example

Letâ€™s take an example of how we might intuitively look at a dataset to determine if its â€œtidy-nessâ€. Consider the following hypothetical table that is tracking student records at a local school.

Name StudentID Age_and_Sex Science_Score Math_Score English_Score
Robert S001 18 M 90 95 70
John S002 15 M 88 79 60
Jane S003 17 F 50 50 55
Abdul S004 14 M 70 90 100
Tracy S005 16 F 40 100 90

What do you notice? Based off the rules that we have, we have a couple of violations. Letâ€™s reflect this against the Tidy Principles:

1. Each column is a variable.

Although each column could be considered a variable, the context is wanting. Although Name and StudentID satisfy this rule, we can clearly see that the â€œAge_and_Sexâ€ variables seems to represent two variables fused as one (Age and Sex).

Also notice the variables for each subject score - Science_Score, Math_Score and English_Score. These variable names seem not to be variables but rather values masked as variables - Science, Math and English. In essence, these values should be put under a new variable with an appropriate variable name (e.g. Subject) and the values - the scores - put within a second variable with an appropriate variable name (e.g. Score).

2. Each row is an observation.

Although each row in essence is an observation, the placement of the values would need to change given the above rule violations. Implementing the above changes would reduce the â€œlengthâ€ of each observation - the number of variables captured per observation would reduce from 6 per observation to just 4 (Name, StudentID, Subject, and Score).

3. Each cell (intersection between the column and row) is a SINGLE value.

It was evident that the â€œAge_And_Sexâ€ column had two values instead of just a single value.

Given the above principle violations, the â€œuntidyâ€ data would probably be best structured as follows in order satisfying each of the three Tidy Principles:

Name StudentID Age Sex Subject Score
Robert S001 18 M Science 90
Robert S001 18 M Math 95
Robert S001 18 M English 70
John S002 15 M Science 88
John S002 15 M Math 79
John S002 15 M English 60
Jane S003 17 F Science 50
Jane S003 17 F Math 50
Jane S003 17 F English 55
Abdul S004 14 M Science 70
Abdul S004 14 M Math 90
Abdul S004 14 M English 100
Tracy S005 16 F Science 40
Tracy S005 16 F Math 100
Tracy S005 16 F English 90

Conclusion

Focusing on cleaning oneâ€™s data set into a tidy dataset helps to set one up for success, making it easier to use functions that comply with the tidy principles in oneâ€™s analysis. It may take a bit of work to get it right but once its done appropriately, it is quite powerful.
